case_vignette: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pin prick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Since the pain started, I can't work, and I'm fully dependent on my wife for everything; I've also noticed that I can't really feel light touches on my whole right arm and forearm.

Thank you for sharing this information. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that you may have a peripheral neuropathy, which is a condition that affects the nerves in your arms and legs. This can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in the affected area.

Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Have you noticed any changes in your sensation, such as numbness or tingling, in other parts of your body? Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as muscle weakness or fatigue?

It's important to determine the underlying cause of your symptoms, so I will need to ask you some more questions. Please answer them as accurately and thoroughly as possible.

I haven't noticed numbness or tingling in other parts of my body, but there is weakness in my right arm and I've been feeling very tired, especially after working several night shifts and looking after my daughter.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that you may have a condition called peripheral neuropathy, which is a common side effect of night shift work. This condition can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in the arms and legs, as well as fatigue and muscle weakness.

Other possible causes of your symptoms could include a vitamin deficiency, such as B12 or vitamin D deficiency, or an underlying medical condition, such as diabetes or thyroid disorder.

I would recommend that you speak with your primary care physician to rule out any underlying medical conditions that may be causing your symptoms. In the meantime, here are some things you can try to help manage your symptoms:

1. Take regular breaks: When working night shifts, it's important to take regular breaks to stretch and move around. This can help reduce the risk of developing peripheral neuropathy.
2. Exercise regularly: Regular exercise can help improve circulation and reduce the risk of developing peripheral neuropathy.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having severe pain in my right arm for the past three days and I can't move it at all.

Yes, I have no feeling to light touch over my entire right arm and forearm.
Great, that helps to narrow it down. Have you experienced any recent trauma or injuries to your arm or shoulder?
No, the symptoms started when I woke up one morning after sleeping on my side.
I see. Have you noticed any weakness or paralysis of your right arm or hand?
Yes, my right arm is extremely weak, and I've been given a muscle strength score of 1 out of 5.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your weakness and paralysis:

1. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as difficulty speaking, swallowing, or breathing?
2. Have you experienced any recent illnesses or infections?
3. Have you been exposed to any toxins or chemicals that could cause neurological symptoms?
4. Have you had any previous neurological conditions or surgeries?
5. Do you have a family history of neurological disorders?

Please answer these questions to help me better understand your situation and make an accurate diagnosis.

I haven't experienced any difficulty speaking, swallowing, or breathing, no recent illnesses or infections, no exposure to toxins or chemicals, no previous neurological conditions or surgeries, and no family history of neurological disorders.

Great, that helps to rule out some potential causes of your symptoms. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a brainstem stroke or other brainstem injury as the cause of your weakness and paralysis.

A brainstem stroke occurs when there is a lack of blood flow to the brainstem, which can cause damage to the nerves responsible for controlling muscle movement, balance, and other functions. This can result in sudden weakness or paralysis on one side of the body, difficulty speaking, swallowing, or breathing, and other symptoms.

Do you have any history of high blood pressure, diabetes, or other conditions that could increase the risk of a brainstem stroke?

I would like to schedule an MRI of your brain to rule out any structural abnormalities that could be causing your symptoms. Additionally, I would like to perform a series of neurological tests to assess your muscle strength, reflexes, and coordination. These tests can help us identify any areas of brain function that may be affected.

Do you have any questions or concerns about these tests?
I understand, and no, I don't have any questions or concerns about these tests right now.

Great, let's proceed with the tests. I will schedule an MRI of your brain for tomorrow morning at 9 AM. As for the neurological tests, I will have you come in for a series of tests over the next few days. We will start with a simple balance test tomorrow afternoon at 2 PM.

Please make sure to fast for at least 8 hours before the tests, and avoid any medications that could affect the results. Also, please bring a friend or family member with you to the tests for support and to help us interpret the results.

Is there anything else you would like to know or discuss before we proceed?
No, that sounds good, and I'll make sure to follow the instructions and bring someone with me. Thank you.

You're welcome! I'm glad you're cooperative. I'll see you tomorrow morning at 9 AM for the MRI, and the following day at 2 PM for the neurological tests. If you have any questions or concerns in the meantime, please don't hesitate to reach out to me or my team. Take care!

Great, thank you for providing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a brachial plexus injury. The brachial plexus is a group of nerves that run from the spine to the arm and hand, and an injury to these nerves can cause weakness, numbness, and tingling in the arm and hand.

To confirm the diagnosis, I would like to perform a physical examination and order some diagnostic tests. These tests may include nerve conduction studies and electromyography (EMG) to assess the function of the nerves and muscles in your arm and hand.

In terms of treatment, brachial plexus injuries can be challenging to manage, but there are several options available. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to repair the damaged nerves. Physical therapy and rehabilitation can also be helpful in improving function and reducing pain.
